assessment_questions.question: Which calculation method uses both cost and schedule indices to forecast the Estimate at Completion (EAC)?
options: Cumulative CPI Method
SCI (Schedule Cost Index) Method
BAC Method
ETC Method
assessment_questions.explanation: The SCI Method combines both the CPI and SPI indices in the formula EAC = BAC / (CPI Ã— SPI) to create a forecast that accounts for both cost and schedule performance.

assessment_questions.question: What is the primary purpose of Monte Carlo simulation in IPMDAR risk analysis?
options: To eliminate the need for risk management
To simulate thousands of possible project outcomes based on probabilistic inputs
To replace traditional EVM metrics
To comply with DoD regulations without meaningful analysis
assessment_questions.correct_answer: To simulate thousands of possible project outcomes based on probabilistic inputs
assessment_questions.explanation: Monte Carlo simulation allows risk analysts to run thousands of simulations with different random variables to generate a probability distribution of possible project outcomes.

assessment_questions.question: Which of the following is NOT typically included in a risk-adjusted EAC?
options: Known performance variances to date
Probabilistic assessment of identified risks
Contractor profit margins
Management reserve considerations
assessment_questions.explanation: Contractor profit margins are not typically included in risk-adjusted EACs. These estimates focus on project cost elements affected by performance and risk factors, not contractual profit arrangements.

assessment_questions.question: When integrating risk data with EVM in IPMDAR, which approach is considered best practice?
options: Keeping risk analysis and EVM data completely separate
Replacing EVM data with risk analysis data
Performing quantitative risk assessment only after EVM data shows problems
Integrating risk impacts into EVM forecasts to create risk-adjusted EACs
assessment_questions.correct_answer: Integrating risk impacts into EVM forecasts to create risk-adjusted EACs
assessment_questions.explanation: Best practice involves integrating risk assessment data into EVM forecasts to create comprehensive risk-adjusted EACs that account for both current performance and future risk impacts.

assessment_questions.question: What is the correct interpretation of an 80% confidence level in a risk-adjusted schedule?
options: There is an 80% chance the project will finish early
There is an 80% chance the project will finish on the estimated completion date or earlier
At least 80% of project tasks will be completed on time
The schedule has been padded with 80% additional time
assessment_questions.correct_answer: There is an 80% chance the project will finish on the estimated completion date or earlier
assessment_questions.explanation: An 80% confidence level means there is an 80% probability that the project will complete on or before the estimated completion date, based on the risk analysis performed.
